column11: Review Text

On 23rd November 2025, our group of thirteen embarked on a memorable journey with Flamingo Lanka tours to visit this historically significant temple, as part of our tour to the UNESCO world heritage city, Anuradhapura.  Constructed by King Devanampiyathissa (247-207 BC), Thuparamaya is recognised as the very first stupa constructed in Sri Lanka following the introduction of Buddhism to the island.  Thuparamaya stands as a testament to the island’s rich cultural heritage. The original stupa renovated in 1862, now features a striking bell-shaped dome.  It rises to a height of 63 feet, with a base diameter of 59 feet.  Surrounding the stupa are four concentric circles of stone pillars, believed to have once supported a conical wooden roof that sheltered the original stupa. The tops of these pillars are adorned with intricately carved lotus buds, showcasing the exceptional craftsmanship of ancient artisans. At the entrance are beautifully carved guard stones, classic examples of ancient Sri Lankan art. As is customary at all sacred Buddhist sites, we dressed modestly and removed our footwear before ascending the platform.  Visiting around 11 am, we found the granite floor quite warm underfoot, making us realize that an early morning or evening visit would have been more comfortable. Following tradition, we walked clockwise around the stupa.  The Buddhists among us, joined the crowds in offering flowers and chanting pirith (Buddhist stanzas), paying homage to the Buddha and his teachings.  The serene and tranquil atmosphere of the temple left a lasting impression on all of us. Thuparamaya is not only a site of great historical importance but also a place where visitors can experience the peaceful spirituality that defines Sri Lanka’s Buddhist heritage. I highly recommend visiting during the cooler hours of the day to fully appreciate the beauty and serenity of this ancient monument.

column8: A picturesque stupa in the heart of Anuradhapura, Sri Lanka.
column11: Perhaps one of the earliest buddha stupas in Sri Lanka, the ruins of old stupa have been left intact and a new stupa is built at the came campus. the place is crowed with ice cream vendors. the picturesque pillars around the new stupa were originally designed to prevent wild elephants from damaging the stupa. A possible visit if you have time to spare.

Dagoba of Thuparama – Sri Lanka’s Oldest Stupa The Dagoba of Thuparama, located in Anuradhapura, is the oldest stupa in Sri Lanka and a significant Buddhist pilgrimage site. Built in the 3rd century BCE by King Devanampiya Tissa, this sacred monument is believed to enshrine the right collarbone relic of Lord Buddha, making it a highly revered location for Buddhists. Highlights: ✅ Historical Significance – Thuparama is considered Sri Lanka’s first stupa, marking the introduction of Buddhism to the island. ✅ Unique Architecture – Unlike other stupas, Thuparama originally had an ‘vatadage’ (circular relic house) surrounding it, remnants of which can still be seen today. ✅ Peaceful Atmosphere – The site exudes serenity, making it a perfect place for meditation and reflection. ✅ Cultural Importance – Regular religious rituals take place, with many devotees offering flowers and prayers. ✅ Surrounding Ruins – The area around the stupa features ancient pillars, stone carvings, and other remnants of Anuradhapura’s glorious past.

column8: The oldest documented Buddhist Stupa in Sri Lanka
column11: Thuparamaya is the oldest documented Buddhist temple in Sri Lanka, a testament to the arrival of Mahinda Thera and the introduction of Buddhism to the island. Nestled within the hallowed grounds of Mahamewna Park, the magnificent Thuparamaya Stupa is the very first Dagoba ever built on the island, dating back to the reign of King Devanampiya Tissa (247-207 BC). This sacred temple has been officially recognized by the Government and designated as a protected archaeological site in Sri Lanka. Join us on a journey through time and history as we explore the ancient wonders of Thuparamaya!

If you are a history buff you will love going into this very old temple site. Beautifully located and maintained, this dagoba is well worth the visit. I am a Christian, but for the Buddhists, this is a place of pilgrimage, so you will streams of people in white carrying flowers to worship. Lovely site.

Very impressive and very beautiful stupa. I was struck by the many faithful in prayer who, as in all temples, donated flowers in homage to the Buddha... you can breathe an air of pure mysticism... worth seeing...

This is the earliest documented Buddhist temple in Sri Lanka. It is in Mahamewna park. It is the earliest Dagoba to be constructed on the island dating back to the reign of King Devanampiya  Tissa (247-207BC)
Very pretty, you have to walk along a walk full of stalls with flowers at a ridiculous price, it is very curious to see the pilgrims make their flower offerings and see them meditating....

Thuparamaya is the earliest documented of Buddhist temple in Sri Lanka. It is in Mahamewna Park and is the oldest Dagoba constructed in Sri Lanka, dating back to the reign of King Devanampiya Tisa (247-207 BC)

The original name of this image house is not known; therefore, the builder of this is also unknown. It is thought that this was built by a minister of King Parakramabahu (1153‐1186) called Mahinda to house the tooth relic. Another belief is that this was built by king Vijayabahu I (1070‐1110). This is the only monument among those in Polonnaruwa where the roof is well preserved. Alberga ocho budas, algunos de los cuales se remontan al periodo Anuradhapura. Los gruesos muros del santuario tienen troneras por las que entra la luz al interior y permite que resplandezcan los cristales de piedra caliza de los budas.
This was built by king dewanampiyatissa  celebrating the introduction of Buddhism to srilanka this is  the very first sthupa in here named by combining sthupa for structure and arama monastery

Built by king Dewanampiyatissa in 2nd century. Originally it was in the shape of a heap of paddy but as restorations were done in later years, it took the form as seen today. The story of the stupa, its immaculate white

In a beautiful woodland setting north of the Ruvanvelisaya Dagoba, the Thuparama Dagoba is the oldest dagoba in Sri Lanka – indeed, probably the oldest visible dagoba in the world. It was constructed by King Devanampiya Tissa in the 3rd century BC and is said to enshrine the right collarbone of the Buddha. Its ‘heap-of-paddy-rice’ shape was restored in 1862 to a more conventional bell shape and to a height of 19m.

This is the first Buddhist Temple in Sri Lanka, built since 3rd century, to house the right collar-bone of Buddha. There are nearby ruins site with some interesting stone carvings especially the famous “Moondtone” carvings which is semicircular usually stood at the foot of first step in Buddhist buildings/ temple. We even explored further to the Elephant Pond as the given name is due to the huge size of the pond. More details to see along the history of Anuradhapura Kingdom in relation to Buddhism culture. It is inclusive in the entrance fee of USD25 or LKR4,550 for the Anuradhapura ancient sites. Hiring a driver is necessary to the scarcity of the site.

Tucked away in the southwestern corner of the Quadrangle is the smallest gedige [a hollow Buddhist temple with thick walls] at Polonnaruwa. Its roof is in situ. Four standing Bodhisattva statues are inside. It dates from the reign of Vijayabahu or Parakramabahu I. A British archaeologist mistakenly gave the building its present name relating to ‘the stupa’ but it is a gedige, a rectangular image house. Thick walls make for a refreshingly cool interior. Suffice to say the scaffolding implies long term betterment but for the short term it evidently negatively impacts one's impression of the building.
The oldest of the sacred sites in this area although heavily restored. Has a nice atmosphere and is worth seeing as part of the sacred city

The first dagoba, or stupa, in the area was built to house the right collar bone relic of the Budddha. It was likely the first dagoba built in the country after the introduction of Buddhism. Its root 'aramaya' is a residential complex for monks. This was a photo only visit without access.
An important monument in Polonnaruwa, Thuparama wows you with its beauty and religious significance.
The structure is inspiring - pious worshippers, statues of Lord Buddha all around, calm ambience - your mind is busy wondering!

Built by king dewanampiyatissa in 2nd century bc.first historic stupa in srilanka building material was clay from basawakkulama tank piled in the form of a heap of paddy and covered with a layer of brick .enshrined right collar bone relic of the buddha.most of its features are lost except for few stone pillars remains of the canapy.last renovation was done in 1862  .
Nice dagoba with usually many religious people clad in white attire praying, making for an interesting photo op

One of several important Ancient moments at Anuradhapura. Quite striking. Be sure to dress modestly (no shorts, or bare shoulders for women) to be respectful. Also required to remove shoes, and be prepared the sand surrounding the dragons can get very hot, and has the occasional sharp stones.
That is a small and very beautiful religious place called stupa of the thuparamaya.that is a most valuable asset of the historical kingdom of anuradhapura
Thuparamaya is small stupsa but it is the first Buddhist temple in Sri Lanka. It was constructed in, dating back to the reign of King Devanampiya Tissa (247-207 BC).

Thuparama  Dagoba is one of the smallest dagobas but it is apparently the oldest of the dagobas. It is a fascinating place to visit and is busy with worshippers and full of life as a result.I suggest that you have socks with you as if you are walking around barefoot the floor can get really hot.

A small temple, but worth a visit, as there are buddha images to admire, and quite, an architecturally interesting structure as it is the only one left with a roof, built in the style that is prevalent in the Polonnaruwa, complex.

Visited Thuparama during a cycle tour of the various dagobas in Anuradhapure. Thuparama is one of the smaller dagobas in town but it's the most fascinating as it's one of the most popular places of worship in Anuradhapura (unlike many of the others) and is full of life as a result.  It's also said to be the oldest Buddhist temple in Sri Lanka. A visit won't take long at all but its well worth it. It easy to find a spot to lock up a bike too.  There's no entrance fee to visit. Just make sure you take socks as if you are walking around barefoot the floor can get really hot.
This temple is quite small but worth spending a few minutes visiting.  It is located adjacent to the main Quadrangle

Thuparama is a relatively smaller "Stupa" of many in the ancient city of Anuradhapura with a well known history of over 2400 years.  The specialty of this is the stone pillars located around it indicating the existence of a timber structure to act as a roof for this small "Stupa" or the dome shaped brick structure.  This is a good place for those interested in meditating and it is located pretty close to the other main and large "Stupa" called Ruwanweliseya.    The path between these two could be an ideal place for those interested in practicing walking meditation to calm the mind by concentrating on the steps while walking slowly.

The Dagoba of Thuparama is one of the smaller but still impressive Dagobas in the sacred city. It's one of the few in this area which is still used as a holy place and temple. While you're here for admiring the beauty of this Dagoba, others came for worshipping. Please behave respectfully as well as dress appropriately, cover your shoulders and knees. No shoes allowed.

The best part about this particular attraction is that there are at least 5 sites to see within close proximity to each other.  Thuparama is situated the furthest away from the car park close to trees.  Visitors must remove their shoes to enter.  The naughty monkeys like to linger nearby.  We witnessed the commotion when one monkey stole someone's sneaker.  One of the employees had to walk to the back to retrieve the shoe after the monkey lost interest in it.  It is dark, dusty and hot inside.

One of the smaller dagobas it is still an active site of worship unlike some of the larger historic dagobas so actually had more people here than at what I would have considered the more impressive sites, but that's because most people here were locals in peaceful contemplation not tourists.

The columns standing around the stupa are what remain of the ancient building first built here. I didnt think ahead, and visited in the middle of the day, when the stone is hot hot hot. My feet didnt feel very good when I put my shoes back on.

The Thuparama is the first stupa built in Sri Lanka after the introduction of Buddhism, and it was built during the reign of King Devanampiya Tissa (about 300 BC) to enshrine the right collar bone of Buddha. Originally it was in the shape of a heap of paddy but as restorations were done in later years, it took the form as seen today. The story of the stupa, its immaculate white color and the brown, ancient stone pillars surrounding it, give it a strange, special aura and make it, in our opinion, the most interesting stupa in Anuradhapura.

This is the only ruined structure among the Polonnaruwa ruins, that still has its roof intact to a great extant. The walls and the roof of the structure are made of bricks. The entry into the structure is allowed and so also the photography. There are few statues of Buddha inside Thuparama, some of which are partially damaged. How the bricks have been laid along the wall and the roof can be seen from the inside of the structure.
This is one of the old Buddhist temple here. The Dagoba is surrounded by old pillars.This is beautiful temple you need about half an hour here.
This was built by King Dewanampiyathissa celebrating the introduction of Buddhism to Sri Lanka. This is the very first stupa in here. Named by combining Stupa for structure and Arama for monastery.
The pillars make the temple looks stunning. There are many ancient rocks around the area. The temple itself is pretty.
This would be one of the list of temples in your tour. Must see the moon stone near the entrance. The pillars are very tempting.
This is one of the most beautiful stupa shaped like a bell. The stone pillars add beauty to this shrine.
We came to visit at the time of the holiday so there were a lot of Buddhists. They did not mind, as I believe that they are constantly interupted by the tourists.
Thuparama is one of the ancient ruins at the Mahamewna Park in Polonnaruwa which will take you back centuries. A must see. Pls include this to your bucket list...

Thuparamaya is the oldest stupa in Sri Lanka and the first to be built in the country after the introduction of Buddhism. It was built in the time of King Devamnampiyatissa (247BC – 207BC) enshrining the collarbone relic of Gauthama Buddha which was brought to Sri Lanka by Arahat Mahinda, son of King Ashoka of India. This is believed to be the oldest Dagaba In Sri Lanka and perhaps in the whole world. It is renovated and well preserved presently. Dagaba is small in comparison to other Dagabas in Anuradhapura and its shape is different and unique. The entrance fee: 25 dollars  and get a DVD in the package.  Actually Thuparama Stupa during that time has been built using clay but several times it was renovated by various kings. It is a reputedly the oldest Dagoba in the world, Thuparama is surrounded by carefully placed pillars where the enhance make a visual appeal dramatically. We went to see this beautiful place in the morning which was great and the stone ground was still cool. Several shaped stupas can be seen in Sri Lanka like bubble shape, bell shape, heap of paddy shape and pottery shape. The Buddha Statue is covered with a vatadage (roof and pillars building) so even today it can be seen that the tall granite pillars surround the stupa. It is believed that this is the first stupa has been built in Sri Lanka. This dagoba is much different from the others, first because it isn´t that big and second because of the stone columns surrounding it. This dagoba is very sacred to Buddhists because they believe that there is the collarbone of the Buddha is found inside. A lot of locals come from all over the country. Decently and nicely dressed and most of them are clad in white.  Get some socks because the ground is very hot during the day. I have to say that this was my favorite sight in Anuradhapura as it was very different from the other places we looked around. To see this dagoba was just tantalizing as it has these pillars around it that make you think of Roman or Greek ruins instead of Asian. The pillars were used to support the roof that once spanned over the Dagoba to protect it. You have to go and see it for yourself to understand truly well. Sri Lanka first - but probably one of the oldest still Dagabas/ stupas  can be seen all over the world   and considered to be the Theravada Buddhism's most sacred place. It is not too big, but very charming and the structure of circle sanctuary (vatadage) very interesting. Don't miss it! Old Sri Lankans certainly knew how to present a building back then which is marvellous. It is also situated in a lovely green parkland area. If you're lucky, you'll have a brilliant blue sky as contrast for your photographs. Compared to Ruwanweli-saya Pagoda, the Anuradhapura stupa is much smaller. Nevertheless, I personally like this stupa and its stone pillars around. It is considered as the first stupa in Sri Lanka. We unexpectedly arrived on a Saturday and could witness and took part in those rituals. The locals wear all-white clothes to enter the place, bringing lotus and various offerings to the stupa. Don't forget, hat and shoes forbidden inside the sacred area. You will need sun protection cream, and wearing socks is very practical to avoid the pain  when trampling small stones / sand and to beat the heat if you visit during hot afternoons. The reason not just the dirty floor (these places wasn't really dirty), very often the stone very hot without shoes. The surrounding is peaceful and calm. I highly recommend you to visit. For us, this was the best visit in all the Unesco site. The columns around the Dagoba give it a unique charm and "special" feeling, compared with the similar looking (in style) constructions. It's nice to visit by bike. Next to this dagoba ther are the ruins of ancient temple which is worth seeing as well. I recommend you, before the visit you must read some historical fact about this place and it would help you to do an interesting the visit.

A smaller dagoba, compared to its larger brothers, but particularly interesting due to the circular columns (actually two circles) that surround the building itself. It is one of the ten-ish places you have to visit in Anuradhapura.

Unfortunately this was our last stop in a big day out of sightseeing.The monks were meditating whilst we were there and I didn’t want to get in their way.The floor was boiling and I had to move quickly and hop around to stop my feet burning.Not much different to other Dagobas that we visited
The stupa and its immediate surrounding buildings and the art work and carvings in the building are remarkable, but the larger area also has many more interesting ruins.
it was so under whelming that we didn't even get out of the car to see it. took photos becausee the guide insisted we do it.

The oldest although it doesn't look old or simple, with a courtyard, shrines around the base, and the interesting stone pillars all over the place.  Probably the most interesting dagoba here but not full of people.  Don't miss the simple brick shrine outside covering buddha's footprint.
Thuparamaya  is the oldest  Dagaba in Sri Lanka . It   has a unique architectural feature called "vatadage", This  stupa was built by  King Dewanampiyatissa. must visit ...sacred place to visit

Thuparamaya Stupa (or Dagoba) is the first stupa in Sri Lanka, according to the history. But there are some evidence to say that there is an earlier one. Anyhow, Thuparamaya is the beginning of the era of Buddhist Temples. Apart from the religious value, this place is highly recommended for a person who loves archeological values. The place is full of archeological ruins. There are ruins of lots of buildings. The place was a temple which facilitate number of monks. So the buildings must have been spread over large area. Most of the existing parts of the buildings are made of stones, such as, stone pillars, stone steps, stone walls etc. (see the photos). Among them, the stone pillars around the stupa is amazing. There said to be a dome to cover the stupa and the pillars were the structural support for the dome. Further, there are a lot of stone carvings such as Guard Stones, Sandakadapahana, Korawak Gala, carved stone pillars etc. The pillars around the stupa is also beautifully carved. This is a must-visit place if you visit Anuradhapura.

Thuparamaya was built by King Devanampiyatissa (250BC - 210BC) and it is the first stupa built after introduction of Buddhism. The collarbone of Lord Buddha is enshrined there. A must visit place for all the Buddhists.
This building is in a better condition than most of the other ruins.There old statues inside worth the visit.You need about half hour here.
Thuparamaya is an ancient Buddhist temple in Anuradhapura.Thuparamaya dagoba has been built in the shape of a bell.If you travel to Anuradhapura, don't forget to visit Thuparamaya.

The Thuparamaya Stupa is the earliest Dagoba to be constructed in the island, dating back to the reign of King Devanampiya Tissa (247-207 BC). It is just few minutes away from Ruwanweliseya. If you are in Ruwanweliseya and have some minutes to spare should visit this. Since this is a sacred place please don't wear short skirts and exposing blouses. Also if you are visiting on day time it can be very hot, recommend wearing socks.
This is towards the back of the Sacred Quadrangle and more or less intact in the sense that you can still see the roof the building. Has many Buddha statues within it.

Easily accessible. But since it is easy to get lost in Anuradhapura it would be best get a good detailed map to get familiar with the roads inside the sacred city and the new city. The car park at Thuparamaya for cars and vans is terrible with uneven ground.  It is better to go to the vehicle park labelled " three wheeler park" later I noticed that cars, vans and buses were permitted to park there as well.
Yes another Stupa in another former city. The thing with this is that it has clearly gone under same maintenance that to my mind takes away an element of its history.
Another spot of importance to Buddhist devotees, and a study in the design, architecture and construction of the ancient times.
This seemed to be the most religious stupa in the complex with the amount of the people around when I visited and also the various offerings that were being performed here.
If you're going to do the Sacred city tour - wear socks. We didn't and our feet got so hot - by the time we got to this stupa we couldn't be bothered getting out of the tuk tuk

This is one of the smaller stupa's in Anuradhapura, but has more going on at the site than the others and is quite impressive to see. There is more around the area as well, with some ruins from the monastery. As with all temples, you must remove your shoes and dress appropriately. Be aware that the ground can get very hot indeed!
This is really an architectural jewel of Anuradhapura!! If you visit it in the dry and hot season (for example, in April), bring a pair of socks!!

This is the one of the first stupa that is build in Sri lanka . Its not much bigger as other stupas that we see here in Anuradhapura but there s a belief that there was a roof around the stupa but now there s no such roof but we can see the stone pillars around the stupa.
The stupa was built by king Dewanampiyatissa in 2nd century BC and this is the first stupa built by a king in Sri Lanka.

This is one of the earliest monuments of the country and so from that point of view worth a visit. It was not something that takes a great deal of time in itself but it is another one of these places which is a bit of a trek by car to get to. There is not a lot to see as such and I suppose a visit here might be more meaningful or interesting if you are lucky enough to get there when there is any ceremony or something like that going on.

Aftrer an afternoon of visiting dagobas and participatiing in some of the ceremonies we climbed to the top of a lookout where I interacted with local people, sharing a laugh and small talk. I saw a sunset from the topmost tower, offered flowers and took in the sights.
One of the great massive stupas around Anuradhapura, although with little to see up close. Offers one of the most iconic photos in the area.
We did not go inside this Stupa but we did see when we were on our way to Abhayagiri Dagoba. Its beautifully lit with diyas during evening.
According to Sri Lanka historical documents this was the first Pagoda built in Sri Lanka. So if your visiting Anuradhapura as a Buddhist you should visit this place.
Enjoyed the grounds more than the Dagoba. It is a very spiritual place but it was just another Dagoba to me. Had hoped for more.
There were quite a lot of people the time I was here. What a really interesting place to visit. Once again, a sacred place to visit, so be respectful. Nice construction, such a holy place to be.

Reportedly the first stupa constructed in Sri Lanka, it has clearly been heavily reconstructed and the shrines are very modern even looking a bit dukeboxy. Part of the collarbone of the Buddha is believed to be enshrined here, so it is a place of pilgrimage. However, unlike the Boo tree site the atmosphere here is a bit surreal, with someone announcing on a microphone the names of those who have donated and how much.

The history says it's the first stupa constructed in Sri Lanka. Hence, it's not large. However, the existing ruin shows that the stupa had a permanent shelter. It's not a difficult location and famous local visiting place.
One of the oldest Stupas !!! Nice Gem to see and walk along. Great Links with History !!!! Good one !!

The first recorded stupa to be built in Sri Lanka and the legend goes that it enshrines the collarbone of the Buddha . It is a little gem that more than holds its own amongst the larger dagobas in Anuradhapura. For me, it is special given the large number of pilgrims when I visited. PS wear socks if you are visiting during the day - the stones you walk on get hot!
As for all the dagobas here, this is really worth seeing and imagining the scale and beauty of the place in its heyday.

Thuparamaya Dagobah Thuparamaya Dagobah is the oldest historical structure and first stupa built in 3rd century after the introduction of Buddhism in Sri Lanka by King Devanampiyatissa on the request of Mahinda, an envoy of Ashoka, the great Emperor of India. The collarbone of Mahatma Buddha was enshrined in this Dagobah Thuparamaya is derived from the words "stupa" and "aramaya" which means residential complex for bhikshus, hermits and monks. During the course of history, this dagobah was destroyed and rebuilt many times. The present monument was built in 1862 in the shape of a bell with a diameter of 60 feet

One of the oldest & the first Stupas built by an ancient  & famous king called King Devanampiyatissa. It is believed the relics of the collar bone of Lord Buddha is enshrined in this stupa, & the shape of the monument is supposed to be that of a bell. Be appropriately dressed when visiting this site, as a mark of respect to Buddhism. Best time to visit is early morning, up to 11am & evening after 4pm as it can be very hot.

So much to take in and so many Stupas to take in, the twin ponds are also worth visiting and there are some lovely local snacks to be had by the side of the ponds.  The sacred tree is worth visiting and it is interesting to watch the locals wait for a leaf to fall from it, apparently one of the oldest trees in the world the Sri Maha Bodhi has been lovingly tended for 23 centuries.

Thuparama is one of the first dagobas in Sri Lanka. It may not be as big as the other dagobas but it is among the most important. You can spend about 1 hour there. You will hardly find many people except on Poya days. You will some ruins of the stone towers which once held a roof to cover the dagoba from rain and heavy sunlight.

The oldest stupa in Sri Lanka, and really beautiful. It's not the biggest, but it is one of the most beautiful we saw. The surrounding pillars once supported a roof, so you get a sense of the size of the building in which it once sat. If touring Anuradhapura this is a site you should not miss.
We got pissed of when visiting this stupa, coz they poured water everywhere on the top which made dry flower offerings become disgusting and one should walk around in this mess without shoes?

Thuparamaya is the oldest dagoba of Sri Lanka. It was built over an ancient Hindu temple. The dagoba is surrounded by the ruins of the yore that give a scenic look to the place. The locals in white attire make the place look like a lake full of swans. One must carry a pair of socks to visit this place as we have to walk barefoot that gives a feel of firewalk.

Historical stupa and still magnificent to look at. It supposedly contains the Buddha's collarbone. It helps to wear socks as walking up to the  site on the very hot stones and sand pathways can be very difficult in bare feet.
Ancient Dageba in Anuradhapura Mahamewna uyana. you can see the rehabilitated dagaba and the ancient stone columns as it is around it. This located just 5 minutes walk away from Ruwan weli seya.

It's not as big as some other temples but beautiful nonetheless and I believe the oldest in Anuradhapura. The small ruined temple to the right has some lovely carvings at the steps and a beautifully preserved moonstone. Nice to wander around for a few mins
We visited this place along with Family during Christmas holidays and it is a great place to visit and pay homage

This is one of the smallest dagobas in the area and can be visited along the way from one sacred site to another. If you plan to see all 8 sacred sites, this one can be done en route and you may not even have to get out of the car.
All the Stupas and Dagobas must be visited!! They are sort of similar but different in their own way :) Some are massive while some of smaller in size.
This is a compact(small)stupa, said to be containing the collar bone of Buddha,in that respect  it is an important  shrine.A walk around the stupa is recommended.
This is supposed to be the oldest Dageba in Sri Lanka, which was built by king Devanam piyatissa . A must visit for those who explore history of Sri Lanka.

This is believed to be the oldest Dagaba In Sri Lanka and perhaps in the whole world. It is renovated and well preserved.  Dagaba is small in comparison to other dagabas in Anuradhapura and its shape is different too . it is must visit for traveler/ pilgrim in Anuradhapura

Small, but sacred to to Buddhists, this stupa claims the title of the "first one built in Sri Lanka." It offers a great Kodak moment, but I was disappointed to learn that the structure is not ancient at all, but rather a reconstruction undertaken in the mid-19th century. Out guide told us that it was not even rebuilt in the correct shape!

actually thuparama stupa has been built by king devanampiyathissa 3rd centuryBC .that time it has been built using clay but several time renovated by various kings. several shapes stupas can be seen in sri lanka then bubble shape,bell shape,heap of paddy shape ,and pottery shape.enshrine in inside buddhas collarbone and now bell shape but that time this sthupa taken heap of paddy shape.surround covered with vatadage (roof and pillars building)so even today can be seen tall granite pillars surround the stupa .historically believed this is the first stupa has been built in sri lanka..

I went to see this beautiful place in the morning which was great because there was almost no people and the stone ground was still cool. This dagoba is much different from the others, first because it isn´t that big and second because of the stone columns surrounding it. This dagoba is very sacred to Buddhists because they believe that there is the collarbone of the Buddha inside. Next to this dagoba ther are the ruins of ancient temple which is worth seeng as well.

Thuparamaya is the oldest stupa in Sri Lanka and the first to be built in the country after the introduction of Buddhism. It was built in the time of King Devamnampiyatissa (247BC – 207BC) enshrining the collarbone relic of Gauthama Buddha which was brought to Sri Lanka by Arahat Mahinda, son of King Ashoka of India.

This is the oldest Stupa in Anuradhapura, probably in Sri Lanka itself. Smaller in size, but quite attractive. This is a functioning temple and hence dress properly (you will see the local people wearing white dress) and remove Shoes and hat while entering the temple. The floor gets very hot during the day and hence better to wear the socks.
This is a lovely peaceful place. Socks are essential to save your feet from the hot ground. When I visited there was no one else there

We visited on a Sunday and the place was busy. A lot of locals come from all over the country. Nicely dressed, mostly in white.  Great opportunity for people watching. Don't walk around barefoot like me. Get some socks because the ground is very hot.

I have to say that this was my favorite sight in Anuradhapura as it was very different from the other places we looked around.  To see this dagoba was just tantalizing as it has these pillars around it that make you think of Roman or Greek ruins instead of Asian.  The pillars were used to support the roof that once spanned over the dagoba to protect it.  You have to go and see it for yourself to truly understand

We really enjoy visiting this place, which has a unique atmosphere. One of the great pleasures of Anuradhapura is the fact that no two constructions are alike and this one is different because of its wonderful columns or pillars which rise some 12 feet into the air in from of it giving the appearance a statement of grandeur. The whole construction is small compared to other buildings in the cultural centre but it is beautifully located in green surroundings and well worth visiting.

Sri Lanka first - but probably one of the oldest still be seen all over the world - stupa and Theravada Buddhism's most sacred place. No too big, but very charming and the structure of circle sanctuary (vatadage) very interesting. Don't miss it! Don't forget, hat and shoes forbidden inside the sacred area. You will need sun protection cream, and exchange socks is very practical. The reason not just the dirty floor (these places wasn't really dirty), very often the stone very hot without shoes. I recommend you, before the visit you must read some historical fact about this place, will be interesting the visit!

Reputedly the oldest dagoba in the world, Thuparama is surrounded by carefully placed pillars which enhance the visual appeal dramatically. They certainly knew how to present a building back then! It is also situated in a lovely green parkland area. If you're lucky, you'll have a brilliant blue sky as contrast for your photographs.
This is a much restored but very old and important dagoba site, quite small in comparison to the others in the area but very much venerated.

For us, this was the best visit in all the Unesco site. The columns around the dagoba give it a unique charm and "special" feeling, compared with the similar looking (in style) constructions. It's nice to visit by bike. When researching for the trip, we decided against Polonnoruwa because Anura would be more atmospheric, mystical and alive. After speaking with other travelers and seeing pictures, I think Polo would have maybe been nicer. What I do find abusive is the entrance fee: 25 dollars is way too much, even if you get a DVD in the package. Most other tourists, guides, people from GHs agreed that much harm is done with these exaggerated prices and the cancellation of the combo ticket. A normal day salary in SL is 1200 rupees. One hour in a bus, is less than 100 rupees. A normal rice and curry costs around 300 - 500 rupees. How on earth can you justify 3259 rupees to pay for an entrance ticket??? I understand we pay more than the locals, but this is probably 40 or 50 times more. Probably to pay a Government with approximately 60 ministers, many of them opponents, friends and family to the President..........
Considered the oldest Buddhist stupa in Sr Lanka, built in the 1st Century BC. Calm and quiet, respectful,place of worship
Festivities were on and some procession was in progress when we were there. Looked better than other dagobas in Anuradhapura.

This site does not attract the tourist crowds that the Ruwanwellseya does yet it possesses the holiest relic, namely the collarbone of Buddha. Small and recently restored it is surrounded by columns which once held up a roof. Similar columns abound all over this vast archaeological site. All are remnants of buildings and their role are roof props. It retains an odd air of peace and serenity in a site which is mobbed at times of Poya, especially in June

The main dagoba does not look very impressive as compared to other Dagoba in Anuradhapura Temple site. But what I find interesting about this temple is it has numerous ancient looking pillars jutting out about 12 ft  high around the main dagoba. Some are vertical and some are tilted. Some are spread over the floor. Not sure the reasons for their existence. Probably to serve as a legacy of the original temple.  As in all temples compound in Sri Lanka, you need to remove your footwear to enter. You need to bear with the afternoon heat and hot floor surface. The crude surface floor is just bearable to walk around.

Compared to Ruwanwelisaya Pagoda, the Anuradhapura stupa is much smaller. Nevertheless, I personally like this stupa and its stone pillars around. It is considered the first stupa in Sri Lanka. Since it is one of the most sacred places in Anuradhapura, there are always a few religious rituals performed here every weekend. We unexpectedly arrived on a saturday and could witness and took part in those rituals. The locals wear all-white clothes to enter the place, bringing lotus and various offerings to the stupa. The surrounding is peaceful and calm. Highly recommended to visit. Entrance ticket to the entire Anuradhapura site is USD 25 / pax.

This is an enormous Stupa of great signifcance.  It is almost too big to photograph so we have more memories than pictures.  Take socks (as this is a 'working' religious site you have to remove your shoes and store them for a few rupees).  We visited near mid day which was too hot, it would have been better earlier or later in the day, but a magnificant sight.

This was a highlight for me during our explorations of Anuradhapura. The dagoba is beautiful, peaceful and the pillars around it look simply stunning. It makes for an incredible photo, and an even better experience to stand there and see it for yourself.

I visited the week before a full moon festival so the Dagoba was white washed and looked amazing. As with all Buddhist temples you need to take off your shoes before going in and as my review title says wear socks. Unfortunately I didn't follow my own advise and with my visit being at noon the sand and bricks were so hot I had to run between shade. That aside the Dagoba was impressive and well worth a visit. Also a short walk to see the Sacred Bo tree which is 2000 years old.
Another Dagaba in the vicinity when you visit the other major attractions in Anuradhapura. Well worth a visit as it has a rich historical value.

This stupa features on the cover of one of the editions of Lonely Planet so you can have fun trying to match up the picture. (we succeeded) It is an attractive small stupa but the pillars impart a somewhat surreal atmosphere. One of the problems with many of the stupas here is that you are expected to removed shoes and hats in the blistering heat. OK for locals who are used to it but hard for soft westerners. We pleaded that we had a problem with skin cancer and they let us off except right at the shrines. Entry fee to Anuradhapura was also extortionately high for foreigners.
Unlike most of the Dagobas, it was small with a few pillars with a small shrine. Very much a recommend to those Buddhists. As a simple tourist it wasn't spectacular.

This is a very small stupa in comparison to the others but the oldest in Sri Lanka and beautiful in it's own way. There is something really beautiful about the stones pillars which surround the stupa .If you are travelling with small kids you can park your vehicle at the back of the stupa and walk around it .

this is the first stupa build in sri lanka after the introduction of buddhism.built by king devanampiyatissa(3rd b.c).this was a stupa as well asan aramic complex.the stupa was build on the instruction of mihindu tero who brought the buddhismto the islandand its believed that the right coliar bone of the buddhais enshrined.it has been built using mud n clay from the near by abhaya tank to the shape of paddy.covering this stupa has been a unique architectural feature called VATADAGE.a stupa house.this construction according to archeologists date to somewhereafter the 7 c a.d as stone pillars  in such circular shrine r met for the first time in the 7 or 8 c ad.many kings have added or altered the structure of the stupa over the course of centuries.the site was completly ransacked during the chola invasion in the 10 c a d.the 3 concentric pillarsstanding right round the stupa r the remaining of the old watadage.they diminishin height from inner most circlesn at one time carried the weight of a domeshaped over the stupa.what we see today is the restoration done in1862 which has endedup the stupa in BELL SHAPE.it is 59feet in height now.

It was “Thera Mahinda” from India who introduced “Theravada Buddhism” to Sri Lanka. He requested from the king in Sri Lanka at that time “King Devanampiyatissa” to build a “Chetiya” as a place of worship by the Buddhist. The Collarbone of “Gautama Budda” was enclosed in the center and the Chetiya was build around it. According to the history This Chetiya was destroyed by enemies several times. This supposed to be the first “Chetiya” build in Sri Lanka. Being a highly respected place of worship by Buddhist around the world this too is visited by most of the tourists.
Not the biggest or oldest Dagaba in this sacred sight. Interesting in that you can watch people at their daily prayers. A great sense of serenity.

The atmosphere at this stupa site was really good, with pilgrims actively worshipping and living feeling about the place.  The monkeys stealing and eating the lotus flowers within moments of pilgrims placing them at the shrines was initially very funny to watch, but ultimately telling about the pilgrims' acceptance of the greater circle of life and existence as they weren't bothered by the monkeys' behavior as many people would be.  A lesson to be learned.

Although a smaller stupa, it is much more photogenic due to the many pillars surrounding it. The temple is still being used and there was a prayer ceremony going on when I visited the place. Easy to get in. No ticket checks.

Good place to stop for a photo and short visit! The stupa is a good blend of old and new and the grounds are well kept. We visited in the afternoon and the stones were hot so get ready for some shadow to shadow hopping.
This is the first Dagaba built by King Devanampiyatissa, it was in ruins, but fortunately it has been restored, & is worshiped by all Buddist who visit anuradhapura.

This dagaba is a construction marvel done by the architects during the 17th century where it is believed that there had been a roof covering the entire dagaba , which was supported with stone pillars. If you measure the area by making a square and intersecting it from the four corners it will get intersected at the centre , where the top of the dagaba called "koth caralla" is located. What we cannot understand is as to how they had used all these geometrical dimensions without the modern equipments or even with out the use of simple tools such as kaleidoscopes. Any person who is interested in studying or observing ancient construction marvels this is also one of the best constructions.
This was featured on the latest cover of the Lonely Planet guide book, to see it in real was breath taking, it's a lovely subject for photography. Do make a point to see it in sun set.

Thuparama, a brick-built gedige (Sinhala: vaulted shrine) is in a fine state of preservation. Thuparma, the oldest image house at Polonnaruwa goes back the reign of King Vijayabahu the first (1055-1110 A.D.). A brick base about one meter high with three projections once carried an image of Buddha, which is now simple a pile of bricks. The stone images in the Thuparama date back to Anuradhapura period.
Well kept Dagoba is nice to visit.  However, we found most Dagoba's to be very similar.
I like this temple since it shows the old remains and the remoddled stupa in white, so you can see the contrast of old and new. The whole visit takes only 5 minutes.

This is the 1st sthupa(domed shrine of worship...usually enclosing some sacred relics) built in SriLanka after the advent of Buddhism to the island 2500 years ago. Though it is a small structure compared to the surrounding monuments in the are, the serenity of its envirenment makes it awe inspiring. The pillars surrounding it (which were the support columns for the covering structure when it was originally built) are sagging in every whichway with the passage of time & has been the subject of many artful paintings. All in all a very special historic site to be visited if making a trip to the ancient city of Anuradhapura in SL.

This is one of the “ata masthana“ (eight worshiped places) in Anuradhapura .if you don’t visit this place your visit to Anuradhapura isn’t complete. Lot of people come here during poya days and it will be packed with worshipers, so it’s good to avoid these days and go

The oldest stupa in Sri Lanka, it is said to enshrine the clavicle of Buddha. The current stupa is a later renovation of the original stupa erected by Devanampiya Tissa in the 3rd century BC. The current bell-shaped stupa is encircled by smaller shrines and stone pillars that 'may' have supported a wooden roof.
